mapping.movement_side: Muscles you don't use get pruned away to save metabolic resources. Your body is ruthlessly efficient - it won't maintain what you don't need.
mapping.tech_side: LLMs compress or prune older context to fit token limits. Unused information gets deprioritized or dropped entirely.
mapping.shared_principle: Use it or lose it - biological and computational systems both optimize for efficiency by pruning unused capacity

movement_tech_metaphors.usage_context: When explaining why desk workers lose mobility, or when discussing how agents handle long conversations
movement_tech_metaphors.example_bridge: Your hip mobility is like an AI's context window - if you don't actively use it, the system will compress it down to just the ranges you actually need. Sit all day? Your body 'prunes' the deep squat pattern.

mapping.movement_side: When injured, your body creates compensation patterns - limp on one leg, shift weight differently, recruit different muscles. It's functional but inefficient and can cause secondary issues.
mapping.tech_side: When an API fails, systems implement fallbacks and graceful degradation. Keeps things running but not optimal.
mapping.shared_principle: Both systems prioritize continued function over optimal performance when primary pathways fail

movement_tech_metaphors.usage_context: When discussing chronic pain from old injuries, or explaining how movement patterns persist after healing
movement_tech_metaphors.example_bridge: That old ankle sprain? Your nervous system built a 'try-catch' block around it - you move differently now to avoid the error state (pain). But like technical debt, those compensation patterns create new problems downstream.

movement_tech_metaphors.movement_concept: Joint range of motion and flexibility
movement_tech_metaphors.tech_concept: API rate limits and throughput constraints

mapping.movement_side: Each joint has a range of motion - how far it can move safely and efficiently. Push beyond it without training and you risk injury or inefficient movement.
mapping.tech_side: APIs have rate limits - maximum throughput before errors or throttling. Stay within limits for smooth operation.
mapping.shared_principle: Both systems have hard constraints that define safe operational boundaries. Gradual expansion is possible but requires systematic approach.

movement_tech_metaphors.usage_context: When discussing flexibility training or why someone can't touch their toes
movement_tech_metaphors.example_bridge: Your hamstring flexibility is like an API rate limit - it's a hard constraint on your system's current capabilities. You can gradually increase it (rate limit upgrades), but trying to force it immediately just throws errors (strain/injury).

mapping.movement_side: Power flows through the kinetic chain - ground force transfers through ankle → knee → hip → trunk → shoulder → hand. Any weak link reduces total output.
mapping.tech_side: Data flows through processing pipelines. Bottlenecks at any stage reduce overall throughput.
mapping.shared_principle: Sequential systems are only as efficient as their weakest link. Optimization requires identifying and addressing bottlenecks.

movement_tech_metaphors.usage_context: When explaining why whole-body movement matters, or why fixing one area doesn't always solve the problem
movement_tech_metaphors.example_bridge: Throwing a ball isn't just about arm strength - it's a data pipeline starting at your feet. Weak core? That's a bottleneck that limits how much force your shoulder can generate, just like a slow database query tanks your entire API response time.

mapping.movement_side: Repeated movements get encoded into procedural memory - you stop consciously thinking about them. Walking, typing, catching a ball become automatic subroutines.
mapping.tech_side: Frequently accessed data gets cached in faster memory layers. Hot paths get optimized so they don't require full computation each time.
mapping.shared_principle: Both systems move frequently-used operations from slow, conscious processing to fast, automatic execution

movement_tech_metaphors.usage_context: When discussing habit formation, movement retraining, or why bad posture is hard to fix
movement_tech_metaphors.example_bridge: Your slouched desk posture is cached in procedural memory - it's the default state your nervous system loads without conscious thought. Fixing it isn't about willpower; it's about cache invalidation and writing new defaults. That takes thousands of reps.
